description.narrative: The project aims to support the parliament in the four main areas of its constitutional responsibility: lawmaking, setting policy direction, executive oversight, and representation.

title.narrative: 00057935 Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia 2014-2016 EU
00057935 Strong Parliament in a Consolidated Democracy 20102013 NETH
Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia, II Phase (2016-2018)
"End-of-project evaluation of the UNDP parliamentary project in Georgia and recommendations"

description.narrative: Increased Functionality of the Parliament.
Elections - elections

1. Availability of Parliament's Institutional Reform Plan (IRP). 2. New mandate for the Parliament's international relations services. 3. Citizen-oriented public outreach activities. Number of Parliament's commitments in Open Government Partnership (OGP). 4. Number of amendments to parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP), including alignment with the latest constitutional changes. 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination system in place and operational. 6. Number of committee action plans in place and operational. 7. Number of staff trainings on legislative and financial monitoring functions (summoning committee meetings, conducting government hearings, organizing public sessions, scrutinizing program budgets, utilizing budget execution and State Audit reports, etc.) 8. Action plan and communications roadmap of Committee on European integration in place and operational. Number of staff trainings on legal harmonization and overall integration issues; knowledge-sharing activities (study visits, conferences) with EU Member States. 9. Number of public outreach activities (Europe Day celebration, media workshops, etc.) on European integration processes.

comment.narrative: 1. The Parliament of Georgia lacks a vision of its development strategy. 2. Insufficient structured approach to international relations. Respective parliamentary services perform only protocol functions. 3. The Parliament's public trust is not sufficient. It lacks transparency and adequate public outreach. 4. Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are not realigned with the latest constitutional amendments. 5. Donor coordination in the Parliament remains ineffective. 6. Parliamentary committees lack strategic approach to exercising their constitutional functions. 7. Law-making and oversight capacities of parliamentary committees remain weak. 8. There is a cross-party consensus in favour of Georgia's accelerated European integration; however, both Members and staff of the Parliament lack sufficient knowledge of European issues. 9. There is a low public awareness on Georgia-European Union relations, where the Parliament has a decisive role to play.

1. Institutional Reform Plan finalized and adopted by the Parliament. 2. Concept on International relations agreed with the Parliament; respective amendments to the parliamentary regulations made. 3. Communications strategy developed. Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan developed. 4. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) initiated 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. 7. Parliamentary staff , including from targeted sector committees have greater capacities for fulfilling their duties 8. Action plan of the Committee on European Integration (CEI), communications roadmap and capacity development plan finalized. .

1. Institutional Reform Plan was finalized and is currently under discussion by the Bureau of the Parliament. The Plan focuses on the current needs and challenges of the Parliament and identifies strategic goals in the direction of lawmaking, government oversight, communications, human resource and financial management. 2. Concept on international relations was approved by the Parliament. Respective amendments to the regulations of the Parliament's International Relations Department were prepared and are pending signature by the Speaker of the Parliament. When approved, the Department will expand its tasks to include parliamentary diplomacy as on of major directions and provide respective services to the MPs. 3. Parliament's communications action plan was developed and is operational. Open Parliament Georgia Action plan was developed and adopted by the Parliament Bureau in July 2015. The Plan contains 18 commitments to further parliamentary openness, transparency, citizen engagement and promote new technologies and innovation. As a result of exemplary cooperation between the Parliament and civils society during the elaboration of the action plan, the Parliament was awarded OGP Government Champions Award during OGP Global Summit in Mexico, in October 2015. 4. Revision of Parliamentary Rules of Procedure is suspended until the next phase of the Project (due to fund shortage) and will resume from late 2016, i.e. after parliamentary elections. 5. New donor coordination mechanism has been developed but has not been initiated yet due to unavailability of the Speaker and his Cabinet. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. As verified under the assessment report by the independent consultant (Kevin Deveaux), the committees have considerably improved their performance as a result of action plans: their work has become more structured, cooperation improved with different stakeholders, staff capacities have increased. 7. Comprehensive capacity de

1. Institutional Reform Plan adopted and operational. 2. Amendments to the regulations of the Parliament's International Relations Department adopted. Staff trained to perform new duties under the updated regulations. 3. Communications Department staff trained to better implement communications action plan. Action plan for next years updated. 4. At least 50% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan commitments implemented. 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. Induction program for newly-elected MPs designed in close cooperation with the Parliament. Respective departments trained to ensure local ownership and sustainability of the process. First phase of induction program conducted. Induction materials prepared and published. 7. Parliament assisted in launching its first program-based budgets. International consultancy provided.

1. Institutional Reform Plan was adopted on 11 May 2016 by the Bureau of the Parliament. It has served as a basis to launch functional analysis in the Parliament which is an on-going process now. 2. Amendments to the Charter of the Parliament's International Relations Department were approved and signed by the Speaker of Parliament in September 2016. The Department plans to recruit new staff members who will be delivered with intensive capacity building trainings in the Project's II Phase (starting from 2017). 3. Communications Department staff has been trained on a number of issues. Next steps for the communications action plan have been developed. 4. Around 60%% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan commitments have been implemented. 5. Donor coordination mechanism has not been operational yet. The work will continue in the Project's II Phase, i.e. with the new parliamentary leadership. 6. Induction program for newly-elected MPs has been designed in close cooperation with the Parliament. Respective departments have been trained to ensure local ownership and sustainability of the process. Induction materials were prepared and published. All three phases of the induction program have been successfully implemented in 2016 and January 20017. 7. International consultancy has been provided to the Parliament in launching its first program-based budgets. Consultancy is still ongoing within the Project's II Phase where three parliamentary structural units (healthcare committee, legal committee and international relations department) will pilot their PBBs in 2017.

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative:
047
The baseline level was 034 excluding the assumed increase in funding from revenues generated by the sister project see below

0625
The ratio of current financing to optimally required financing reached 058 at yearend 2013 according to Financial Scorecard at midterm review This figure takes the total revenues available to PAs and divides it by the optimal funding calculation at 2013 Following MTR the PEB agreed to adjust this target downwards from the original 07 for two reasons First the optimal funding foreseen in the Financial Scorecard increased compared to project outset which made it even more challenging to achieve the planned financing level A more fundamental reason to reduce the target however was that all assumed incremental funding sources are falling somewhat short of their planned additions to system revenues as described below The Project Documents Annex G assumed an improvement of 1114 million from the tourism and concession revenues generated as a result of the sister project 2013 revenues from tourism and concessions amounted to almost 650000 While not all tourism and concession revenues are actually attributable to the sister project for purposes of these calculations they are all attributed to the sister project Nevertheless it seems unlikely that tourism revenues will increase by the planned amount by 2017 An improvement of 1019 million was assumed from State funding So far while there has been a GEL increase in the budget no dollar increase has been achieved the GEL exchange rate weakened from 14GEL in 2008 to 168GEL in 2013 The 2008 baseline was 29 million in State funding for the PAsthe same amount as is shown in 2013 Finally CNFs own target at present is to reach 800000 per annum by 2017 an increase of 300000 from 2013 but still 150000 short of the planned 950000 annual contribution assumed from CNF in the project document If CNF funding can reach 800000 and tourism revenues or the state budget can increase by 200000 the revised 0625 target can be achieved

A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio will be completed for the TE in 2017
612000 disbursed by CNF in 2014 as such established annual target was factually reached
During 2015 CNF plans to disburse 567095 As of June 30 2015 CNF factually disbursed up to 286500 on track to meet the 2015 target Expressed in Euro CNFs main currency CNF support to PAs increases annually but due to the devaluation of the Euro against the the target for 2015 appears lower than planned
Government funding in 2014 increased in GEL by 318 compared to 2013 due to major investments in infrastructure

comment.narrative: To improve resilience of highly exposed regions of Georgia to hydro-meteorological threats that are increasing in frequency and intensity as a result of climate change

Structural and non-structural flood protection measures in high risk areas designed and implemented; Food forecasting and early warning system (FFEWS) for Rioni river basin established; Over 200,000 people enjoy a reduced risk of flooding.

Additional four flood protection structures (totally 10) designed and implemented; About 2 ha. of territories fenced and planted under Agro-forestry Sub-component; Flood Forecasting and Early Warning System (FFEWS) established and launched for Rioni river basin; About 280 000 people covered with Reduced flood risk.

description.narrative: Governance Reform Fund (GRF) project serves the overall objective of further strengthening capacities of the Government of Georgia and increasing its effectiveness and efficiency.

Support the development of an efficient public administration system with a stronger capacity of the government to implement a national development agenda that will strengthen the rule of law and improve conditions for democratic accountability

comment.narrative: Georgia has made considerable progress in making its public administration system more effective, efficient, transparent, and citizen-friendly. International partners and donors have supported the Government of Georgia in these efforts. However, challenges persist in the consistent implementation of evidence-based decision making, policy formulation, long-term strategy development, as well as the retention of institutional capacity. In addition, comprehensive internal reforms and the requirements of implementing the Association Agreement/ DCFTA signed with the EU increase transformational pressures on the system.

description.narrative: 1.1. No. of essential policy reforms developed and led by MRDI in an inclusive and participatory manner 1.2. MRDI providing effective inter-ministerial coordination and support to the regions and municipalities in developing, implementing and monitoring the development plans; 1.3. No. of legal acts related to the regional and local governance reform and development adopted and improved in a participatory manner, based on wide consultations 1.4. Extent of substantive involvement of the Parliamentary Committees in the relevant reforms 1.5. Effective thematic coordination process on regional/local development established 1.6. Total no. of direct beneficiaries 2.1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated)1. No of beneficiaries of the project output (gender disaggregated) 2.2 No. of Regional Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner in project regions; 2.3. No. of Municipal Development Plans and relevant Action Plans developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner and reflected in the programme budgets 2.4. Adequate participation of women and men in the regional development and municipal planning and implementation ensured

comment.narrative: 1. MRDI is in process of designing policy reforms, but none completed so far; Regional Development Commission established but yet to become fully operational; MRDI to enhance its guidance to regions and municipalities; The upcoming reforms of the LSG system require revisions to the key laws and legal acts; Insufficient policy making and capacities of Parliamentary Committees in relevant subject; MRDI has yet to develop system of donor coordination at policy and thematic levels. 2. No beneficiaries of the project output so far; No RDPs available; No LSG has an up-to date MDP; about 10 LSGs have prior experience in working on MDPs, or an outdated MDP. Hence, no LSG have programme budgets reflecting MDP priorities; Women, generally take less than 20% places in discussions and decision-making (11% in Sakrebulos). 3. GOG decree #1182/2012 establishing the basis for training of MRDI, Governors and LSG civil servants; GOG has allocated no budgetary resources for training LSG officials; No systemic and state coordinated trainings organized for LSGs .

1.1 At least 300 person/days of training organized to improve staff capacities in 11 key areas-identified from functional analyses 1.2 At least 3 key policy areas and resources fully decentralized to local government, including : central competencies staff management and incentivisation local development policy and project development monitoring and accounting for resources spent on participatory local and regional development 1.3 By 2015 at least 4 sectoral and cross-sectoral policy debates and legislative discussions facilitated by the Parliamentary Committee on RPSG; At least 10 draft laws related to the regional and local governance reform/ development initiated/moved to the parliamentary readings by the Parliamentary Committees 1.4 By 2015 the national legislation essentially in line with the European charter of local self-governance more than 30 legal acts related to the regional and local governance reform and development adopted and improved 1.5 By 2015 LSG primary competencies widened; By 2015 municipal budgets (excluding Tbilisi) make at least 12% of consolidated budget
2.1 At least 6 regions and at least 20 municipalities have pro-poor development strategies developed and adopted in a participatory and inclusive manner (with participation of at least 40% of women) and resourced 2.2 At least 3 actions from RDPs and at least 10 actions from MDPs implemented; At least 75% of these actions are gender sensitive 2.3 At least 40,000 inhabitants are benefited from the development projects and improved services; At least 40% of beneficiaries are female 2.4 At least 10 municipalities adopting programme budgets in line with the MDPs 2.5 At least 12% of women are elected in local Sakrebulos (up from 10.5%)

1.1 During 2015, 292 person/days of training were organized covering 154 national officials (52% female). 1.2 Ongoing RLD legal expertise supports alignments of more than 170 sectoral laws with the 2014 LSG Code. A number transfer significant areas of competence to municipalities, such as education, childcare, municipal transportation, parking regulations, domestic animals, waste management (i.e. not just waste collection). These amendments will be submitted as a package for Parliamentary consideration and approval in the Spring 2016 session. 1.3 During 2015, Chair and other members of the PC on RPSG participated in following policy meetings/discussions: (1) four Committee and Plenary debates on Law on Development of High Mountainous Regions; (2) workshop on alignment of sectoral laws with 2014 LSG Law and Code; (3) seminar on principles for MPD preparation; (4) study visit to Austrian mountain regions; 4) Study visit on regional development issues in Czech republic and Poland. 1.4 Direct election of Mayors and Gamgebelis introduced in line with the European Charter through the 2014 LSG code. Besides:(a) Law on Development of High Mountainous Regions adopted on 31 July 2015 for implementation of certain support measures from 1 January 2016.(b) Law on Regional Development and Policy Planning, further specifying roles and responsibilities in the field of regional development of the institutions and stakeholders, including village assemblies, completed inter-Ministerial consultations 1.5( a)In addition to competencies for water supply and melioration; housing homeless people, and care of stray animals, cultural heritage monuments, and other transferred by the 2014 LSG Code, agreement was reached between Ministries on transfers of further significant competencies to municipalities, such as education, childcare, municipal transportation, parking regulations, domestic animals, waste management. These amendments will be submitted for Parliamenta

PA official gazettement completed The Government of Georgia undertook efforts at the project development stage to legally establish the Machakhela NP This was agreed by Parliament in April 2012 Detailed boundary demarcation is currently in progress with the support of the project NP Administration has been established and equipped by the Agency of Protected Areas of Georgia Project has supported initial training of NP Administration staff awareness raising within local communities and establishment of the NP administration local authorities and project coordination group as well as refurbishment of NP temporary office within the Machakhela valley

description.narrative: Level of involvement of communities in the management and governance of the NP

comment.narrative: NA

PublicCivil SocietyCommunity PA Planning and Management Governance Board established with proper representation and involvement of local communities in the planning and management of the Machakhela NP by year 2

The Project Coordination Group established and operating that includes local government and community representatives The primary role of this group is to ensure coordination and information sharing during the next 2 years of intense activities to establish the functional capacity of the NP ie boundary and zoning NP Administration training infrastructure and equipment management plan development etc Its secondary important role includes the creation of a mechanism by which the NP and local stakeholders can constructively interact A study of existing and potential mechanisms for maximising practical and meaningful interaction and collaboration between communities living within the borderline of the NP or support zone and the protected area is to be commissioned in the 2nd half of 2015 The study will guide the project on most viable and feasible structures and mechanisms for ensuring community engagement and role in NP management that will be incorporated into the management planning process in 2016

description.narrative: Machakhela NP boundaries and zonation decided and participatory management plan in existence

Clearly defined and consensually agreed boundaries and zones by yr 2
Consensually agreed Management plan exists by yr 3

The project is well on track to meet the target expected date September 2015 A contract to undertake the detailed demarcation and land classification of the NP was selected in April 2015 by the project in agreement with APA The PA boundary demarcation is ongoing including the collection and inputting all existing cartographic land and field surveys data into GIS The contractor closely liaises and informs local government and communities on the progress during implementation of this task This activity is expected to be completed in September 2015 Additionally a contractor has been selected to undertake a detailed resource inventory of the NP and surrounding area baseline studies of biodiversity traditional use cultural heritage etc which will form the baseline for monitoring development of a zoning plan as well as the initial NP management plan scheduled for 2016 The contractor should start its work in August 2015 and complete by February 2016

Both the Agency for Protected Areas and the local municipality have already committed significant resources to the establishment of the NP This includes baseline inputs such as staff basic as well as additional equipment additional used vehicle from APA and as agreed during PPG stage the refurbishment of 4km of the Machakhela valley road by the municipality has been completed during 20142015 project cost around 404000 US

description.narrative: Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC
Assistance to Georgia in preparation of its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) for the fulfillment of the obligations under the UNFCCC.
Biennial Update Report (BUR) completed and submitted to UNFCCC (Y/N). GHG emissions inventory report for 2010-2011 is updated and for 2012-2013 is completed.

comment.narrative: Georgia pledged to submit its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) to the UNFCCC by 2016; National Circumstance Chapter of SNC covers situation until 2012; Georgias GHG inventory submitted to the UNFCCC covers years until 2012; Mitigation strategy is currently being prepared under the TNC; UNEP TNA was completed in September 2012. Georgias First Biennial Update Report will build on the findings and recommendations of Third National Communication, as well as the outcomes of the ongoing complementary projects in the country, and will be submitted to the UNFCCC in 2016.

description.narrative: Land border management between Georgia and Azerbaijan

The overall objective of the project is to improve operational capacities of the border agencies of Azerbaijan and Georgia by ensuring coordinated operations at land border with eventual positive impact on overall security in the region and whole Europe.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Intergovernmental Agreement on border delegates between Georgia and Azerbaijan enforced and operationalised.
2 a. EU Best Practices of border guarding and border surveillance presented to senior operational staff 2.b. Coordinated patrolling by Georgian and Azeri border guards conducted on a regular basis. 2.c. At least 50 senior and operational staff actively participating at the national and bilateral thematic workshops 2.d.Positive feedback of staff on professional skills development training 2.e. Training programs for the border guard agencies of two countries are in place and use
3. New Sector offices built and provided to the project area sectors;Specialised equipment is installed and operational; Border staff trained in the use and maintenance of the new equipment.

comment.narrative: Border Cooperation agreement between Georgia and Azerbaijan is in place. However, the international agreement on border delegates between two countries should be endorsed and additional protocols on cooperation updated. There is also a problem of poor infrastructure on Georgian side of the border, lack of adequate equipment as well as lack of coordinated patrolling along the land border .

1.Basic Training Program for Border Guards updated and endorsed and 15 senior officials of border operating agencies have been trained. 2. List of needed subjects for training identified and prepared 3. More than 20 border officials trained on land border surveillance so far. 4. Construction of two sector office buildings commenced

1. Bilateral agreement on Activities of Border Representatives/Border Commissars between Azerbaijan and Georgian Governments was drafted. Relevant national and bilateral workshops were conducted. 2. The training pro-gramme was elaborated and respective trainers were identified. 28 trainers were trained in the area of Stress and Con-flict management and Second Line Document Inspection. 3. 124 senior and oper-ational staff partici-pated at trainings. 4. Vehicles for Border Police of MIA of Georgia were purchased

comment.narrative:
Baseline 1.1/ Tools (guidelines for teachers; assessment tools, practical training materials, learning plan) necessary for introducing modular teaching programs in non-agricultural vocations is not delivered
Baseline 1.2/ Stakeholders in vocational education and employment for selected municipalities of Shida Kartli and Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti (Tsalenjikha, Mestia, Kareli, Khashuri, Nikozi) has never been identified and consequently no capacity building programmes have been conducted.
Baseline 2.1.1/ Concept of mobile VET unit has never been implemented in Georgia, despite existence of remote mountainous areas with limited access to VET services.
Baseline 2.1.2/ Concept of distance learning and e-learning elements is not applied in vocational education in Georgia neither at the legislature nor at the college level.
Baseline 2.1.3/ On-the-job training is not applied in Georgia
Baseline 2.1.4/ Concept of international mobility of vocational education students is not developed for Georgia and consequently, no training programs exist in international mobility of vocational students for teachers and management
Baseline 2.2.1/ Considering that greater majority of municipalities of Georgia currently are not covered by vocational education institutions, National Strategy of Vocational Education development envisages introduction of vocational education programs in secondary schools. Currently there are no secondary schools in Georgia which conduct vocational education programs.
Baseline 2.2.2/ Formalized platform for partnership between vocational education institutions and private sector is non-existent in Georgia
Baseline 3/ Life-Long-Learning (LLL) system in VET is not developed in Georgia.
Baseline 4.1-4.2/ Currently existing Government employment schemes deal with only job seekers and employers ignoring such important players as Government employment services and service providers, which negatively affects employability and productivity of labour force. Besid

Target 2015: 1.1.1/ Teachers (at least 5 persons) and managers (at least 8 persons) of Tetnuldi college (Mestia municipality) and Lakada college (Tsalenjiha municipality) trained in methodology and management of modular teaching program
1.1.2/ Guidelines for teachers; assessment tools for modular teaching programs of 1 most demanded vocation developed

1.1.1/ Entire administrative and teacher personnel of Vocational Colleges Tetnuldi (Mestia) and Lacada (Djvari) were trained in methodology and management of modular program. Namely 10 management personnel (o/w 7 women) and 16 teachers instead of planned 8 (o/w 10 women) underwent training in following three courses: Modular Vocational Educational Programs, Interactive teaching learning methods in vocational education, Legal and organizational aspects of implementing teaching practice component of vocational education programs.
1.1.2/Teachers guidelines/assessment tools were developed for the modules of 4 most demanded vocational programs (instead of planned 1). Namely for the following vocations/modules: 1/ Low-voltage electrician (4 modules out of 8), 2/ Plumber (2 modules out of 8) 3/ Receptionist: (2 modules out of 8), and 4/ Mountain guide (2 modules out of 8) . Since Mountain guide vocational program is not approved yet by the National Educational Centre of Quality Enhancement, the project has also worked on revising of existing modules based on field piloting results. The project has finalized two modules: Orientation and Navigation and Avalanche Safety with respective guideline and assessment tools.

Target 2016: 1.1.2/ Guidelines for teachers; assessment tools and practical training materials for modular teaching programs of 3 most demanded vocations developed
1.1.3/ Application of above-mentioned instruments in at least 4 modular teaching programs (Tetnuldi and Lakada colleges) monitored
1.2.1/ Needs assessment of potential stakeholders in vocational education and employment in the Government, Parliament and selected municipalities conducted
1.2.2/ At least 2 capacity-building program developed based on identified institutional needs of stakeholders in vocational education and employment
1.2.3/ At least 2/3 of stakeholders from central and municipal levels trained in managing vocational education and employment programs
2.1.1a/ Mobile VET centre for mountainous municipality of Mestia is established/operational 2.1.1b/ At least 60 people retrained and 100 people consulted by Mestia mobile VET unit
2.1.2/ Schemes of distance learning and e-learning implemented in selected vocational colleges and secondary schools (Tetnuldi and Lakada colleges, Agara and Khashuri schools)
2.1.3a/ Organisational Schemes of on-the-job training developed 2.1.3b/ Organizational schemes of on-the-job training implementing in private enterprises of 4 municipalities (Mestia, Tsalenjiha, Kaerli and Khashuri) covering regions of Shida Kartli and Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti
2.1.4a/ Concept of international mobility of vocational education students developed 2.1.4b/ Training programs in international mobility of students for teachers and management personnel elaborated 2.1.4c/ Training in international mobility of students conducted for teachers and management personnel of at least 2 vocational colleges
2.2.1a/ Teachers of Agara and Khashuri secondary schools trained in delivering retraining courses in 4 most demanded vocations locally and in modular teaching
2.2.1b/ Management personnel of Agara and Khashuri secondary schools trained in vocational education management

1.1.2. Guidelines and assessment instruments were developed for all of 4 vocational education programs selected by the project: Low-voltage electrician, Plumber, Receptionist and Mountain guide.
1.2.1. Discussion of main issues that were identified in result of needs assessment conducted with vocational education and employment policy formation participant focus group representatives, and identification of ways of future cooperation.
1.2.2/The stakeholders training was conducted in August in Mestia Municipality Hall on vocational Education and Employment. Seminar was conducted for local authorities and local company representatives (6 companies, mainly representing hotel management and construction) . Objective of the training: review of main aspects and issues of vocational education policy and employment, developing skills for informed decision policy making; comprehending public-private partnership model essence and meaning in vocational education modular educational program during implementation modular teaching, comprehending main aspects of policy making and current policy in vocational education in Georgia.
1.2.3. Public and private sector representatives 16 (including 11 women) Main issues:
Formation of vocational education and employment policy, stakeholders involved in the policy formation and their roles. Internal and external factors that affect vocational education and employment policy formation. International landmarks of vocational education and employment: European association agreement and processes and obligations that are related to the agreement. Legislative base in relation to vocational education and employment Vocational education reform strategy 2013-2020 and action plan of 2013-2017 European qualification framework and national qualification framework. Labor market and employment policy, ongoing issues and international landmarks Employers problems and opportunity to consider the problems during the policy formation process.
